SECRET. 0 Enclosure in Colonial Office Covering Letter Dated 2?th July, 1934, No.37926/34- Colonial Office, Downing Street, 24th July, 1934- Sir, I have the honour to refer to my secret despatch 2 of the 30th April regarding the provision of additional equipment for the police stationed on the Islands of Perim and Kamaran, in the last paragraph of which you were promised a separate despatch on the subject of the special status of Kamaran. 2. In your despatch No. C. 172 of the 24th March, 1933, to the Government of India the statement is made that the responsibility for the defence of the Islands of Perim and Kamaran against an enemy Power in war time would remain with the Officer Commanding, British Forces in Aden; and a similar statement is contained in paragraph 4(a) of the letter from the Officer Commanding British Forces in Aden, dated 18th November, 1933, a copy of which was enclosed with your despatch of the 22nd November, 1933- While this statement is true of Perim, it is not applicable to Kamaran. As you are aware, the Island of Kamaran comes within the scope of Article 16 of the Treaty of Lausanne under the provisions of which its future is left to be settled ’*by the parties concerned'’. Kamaran is, therefore, not a British possession and is only administered by His ivlajesty’s Government, its status being left under the Treaty of Lausanne THE RESIDENT AT ADEN. for/for settlement after consultation between the interested Powers. His Majesty’s Government regard it, however, as a vital Imperial interest that no European Power should establish itself on Kamaran Island and that the island should not fall into the hands of an unfriendly Arab ruler. 3» In these circumstances His Majesty^ Government, while they consider themselves entitled to take such steps as can be shown to be necessary to maintain the status quo on the island, would be unable to sanction such measures as the erection of fortifications or other permanent works, since such measures would be likely to convey the impression that His Majesty* s Government intended to occupy the island permanently and to treat it in fact as a British possession. The same not objection woulc^ however, apply to less formidable precautions, of a non-permanent nature, against attack, such as the strengthening of the garrison, the issue to it of additional arms or the stationing at the island of a warship or service aircraft. In view, nevertheless, of the suspicious attitude of the Italian Government in regard to any action by His Majesty*s Government at Kamaran, the carrying out of even such measures as those referred to in the previous sentence would require careful handling and should not, save in circumstances of great emergency, be taken without reference to His I. ajesty*s Government. The instructions in the previous sentence do not of course apply to normal visits to Kamaran by His Majesty*s sloops and service aircraft. 4* It does not, in point of fact, appear that Kamaran is in the least likely to be the object of organised attack. There is little reason to suppose that King Ibn Saud or the King of the Yemen would seek to challenge the position of His/3 i V. A. % ' m & His Majesty's Government on the island. The Italian Government are committed to the acceptance of the status quo ; and there is small danger of a threat from any other power. It would appear therefore that the principal, if not the only, risk is that of sporadic attacks from the mainland 'by tribesmen from the Arabian coast, in the event of which the permissible defensive measures referred to in the preceding paragraph should be adequate. 5* In the light of the special circumstances to which I have referred above you will no doubt appreciate the importance of dealing separately with all questions relating to the island of Kamaran, and of ensuring that any measures which it may be necessary to take in connection with the island should be quite distinct from any measures taken in connection with British possessions such as Perira. I shall be grateful if this distinction may be clearly borne in mind, and if any necessary instructions may be given to secure that the principles enunciated in this despatch are not inadvertently infringed. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in rough chronological order from the rear to the front of the file

The foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 15; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Aden Resident, the Colonial Office, the Foreign Office, and the Government of India Foreign and Political Department.The correspondence concerns the question of applying sanctions at Kamaran, in light of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute. The legal and administrative status of Kamaran is discussed, in the context of British responsibilities under Article 16 of the Treaty of Lausanne, and Article 16 of the Covenant of the League of Nations.The file includes a divider which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the end of the correspondence (folio 1).
